pageProps.body:
The Chain Rule

So apparently derivatives are fractions now.

The univariate chain rule, revisited

Definition. A composite function (of one variable) is a function of the form f(x)f(x)f(x) where xxx is itself a function of another variable ttt: x=g(t)x = g(t)x=g(t).

The chain rule in 1D aims to answer the question: if fff depends on xxx and xxx depends on ttt, how does fff change when ttt change? - i.e. what is dfdt\frac{df}{dt}dtdf​? The two ways of notating the result are either

dfdt=f′(g(t))g′(t)\frac{df}{dt} = f'(g(t))g'(t)dtdf​=f′(g(t))g′(t)

or

dfdt=dfdxdxdt\frac{df}{dt} = \frac{df}{dx}\frac{dx}{dt}dtdf​=dxdf​dtdx​

but they speak the same meaning: the rate of change of fff with respect to ttt is the rate of change of fff with respect to xxx, multiplied by the rate of change of xxx with respect to ttt.

Caution. You will use the second notation, and if you use the first notation, I will personally call 911 and notify the Cringe Police of England that it's cringe-o-clock on your sorry ass.

You may have also heard a variety of analogies to justify this statement, each more sensible and life-changing than the last: e.g. "to turn the second gear you have to turn the first", "to eat a M&M you eat the chocolate shell before you eat the filling", "to microwave a pregnant mother you microwave the mother with the baby inside then microwave the baby", etc., etc.

Is this a consequence of the divergence theorem?

How can this be generalized to more than one dimension?

The chain rule in 2D

Now consider a function of two variables

z=f(x,y)z = f(x,y)z=f(x,y)

where each of x,yx, yx,y are functions of ttt:

f(x,y)=f(g(t),h(t)).f(x,y) = f(g(t), h(t)).f(x,y)=f(g(t),h(t)).

How does fff change with respect to ttt, i.e. what is dfdt\frac{df}{dt}dtdf​? The multivariate chain rule states that

Theorem. Multivariate chain rule, Case 1 (functions of one variable). For a (scalar function of two variables z=f(x,y)=f(g(t),h(t))z=f(x,y)=f(g(t),h(t))z=f(x,y)=f(g(t),h(t)),

dfdt=∂f∂xdxdt+∂f∂ydydt\frac{df}{dt} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt}dtdf​=∂x∂f​dtdx​+∂y∂f​dtdy​

Proof.

Think back to the linear approximation of fff near an arbitrary point x,yx, yx,y, where the incremental Δz=f(x+Δx,y+Δy)−f(x,y)\Delta z = f(x+\Delta x, y + \Delta y) - f(x,y)Δz=f(x+Δx,y+Δy)−f(x,y) equalled

Δz=fxΔx+fyΔy+ϵ1Δx+ϵ2Δy\Delta z = f_x \Delta x + f_y \Delta y + \epsilon_1 \Delta x + \epsilon_2 \Delta yΔz=fx​Δx+fy​Δy+ϵ1​Δx+ϵ2​Δy

with the error terms ϵ1,ϵ2\epsilon_1, \epsilon_2ϵ1​,ϵ2​ tending to 000 as Δx,Δy\Delta x, \Delta yΔx,Δy tend to 0, as long as fff is differentiable at that point. As x=g(t)x = g(t)x=g(t) and y=h(t)y = h(t)y=h(t) respectively, we write:

{Δx=g(t+Δt)−g(t)Δy=h(t+Δt)−h(t)\begin{cases} \Delta x = g(t+\Delta t) - g(t) \\ \Delta y = h(t+\Delta t) - h(t) \end{cases}{Δx=g(t+Δt)−g(t)Δy=h(t+Δt)−h(t)​

To obtain dfdt\frac{df}{dt}dtdf​, we divide Δz\Delta zΔz by Δt\Delta tΔt

ΔzΔt=fxΔxΔt+fyΔyΔt+ϵ1ΔxΔt+ϵ2ΔyΔt\frac{\Delta z}{\Delta t} = f_x \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} + f_y \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta t} + \epsilon_1 \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} + \epsilon_2 \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta t}ΔtΔz​=fx​ΔtΔx​+fy​ΔtΔy​+ϵ1​ΔtΔx​+ϵ2​ΔtΔy​

and suppose that Δt\Delta tΔt tends to 000, so that ΔzΔt→dzdt\frac{\Delta z}{\Delta t} \to \frac{dz}{dt}ΔtΔz​→dtdz​. Then Δx→g(t)−g(t)=0\Delta x \to g(t) - g(t) = 0Δx→g(t)−g(t)=0 and similarly Δy→h(t)−h(t)=0\Delta y \to h(t) - h(t) = 0Δy→h(t)−h(t)=0; as such ϵ1\epsilon_1ϵ1​ and ϵ2\epsilon_2ϵ2​ both tend to 000. Therefore

ΔzΔt=fxΔxΔt+fyΔyΔt\frac{\Delta z}{\Delta t} = f_x \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} + f_y \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta t}ΔtΔz​=fx​ΔtΔx​+fy​ΔtΔy​

without the error terms, and as

Δt→0,{ΔzΔt=dzdtΔyΔt=dydtΔxΔt=dsdt\Delta t \to 0, \begin{cases} \frac{\Delta z}{\Delta t} = \frac{dz}{dt} \\ \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta t} = \frac{dy}{dt} \\ \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{ds}{dt} \end{cases}Δt→0,⎩⎨⎧​ΔtΔz​=dtdz​ΔtΔy​=dtdy​ΔtΔx​=dtds​​

we finally have

dfdt=∂f∂xdxdt+∂f∂ydydt\frac{df}{dt} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt}dtdf​=∂x∂f​dtdx​+∂y∂f​dtdy​

as desired. Note that dfdt\frac{df}{dt}dtdf​ instead of ∂f∂t\frac{\partial f}{\partial t}∂t∂f​ is used because fff is, in reality, a univariate function of ttt.

What if each of xxx, yyy are now themselves multivariate functions, e.g. x=g(s,t)x = g(s,t)x=g(s,t), y=h(s,t)y = h(s,t)y=h(s,t)? Then we have

Theorem. Multivariate chain rule, Case 2 (functions of multiple variables). If z=f(x,y)z = f(x,y)z=f(x,y) instead equals f(g(s,t),h(s,t))f(g(s,t), h(s,t))f(g(s,t),h(s,t)) for some functions of two variables ggg and hhh, then

{∂z∂s=∂z∂x∂x∂s+∂z∂y∂y∂s∂z∂t=∂z∂x∂x∂t+∂z∂y∂y∂t\begin{cases} \frac{\partial z}{\partial s} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial s} \\ \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial t} \end{cases}{∂s∂z​=∂x∂z​∂s∂x​+∂y∂z​∂s∂y​∂t∂z​=∂x∂z​∂t∂x​+∂y∂z​∂t∂y​​

now using ∂\partial∂ instead of ddd because zzz depends on more than one variable.

Proof is similar to above.

This is a classic example of what is known as "proof by handwaving". of course, the above can also be generalized to functions of any number of variables:

Theorem. Generalized multivariate chain rule. Suppose that f(x)=f(x1,x2,...,xm)\mathbf{f(x) = f}(x_1,x_2,...,x_m)f(x)=f(x1​,x2​,...,xm​) is a function of mmm variables f:Rm→Rnf: \mathbb{R^m \to R^n}f:Rm→Rn, with

{x1=u1(t1,t2,...,tl)x2=u2(t1,t2,...,tl)⋮xm=um(t1,t2,...,tl),\begin{cases} x_1 = u_1(t_1, t_2, ..., t_l) \\ x_2 = u_2(t_1, t_2, ..., t_l) \\ \vdots \\ x_m = u_m(t_1, t_2, ..., t_l), \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​x1​=u1​(t1​,t2​,...,tl​)x2​=u2​(t1​,t2​,...,tl​)⋮xm​=um​(t1​,t2​,...,tl​),​

i.e. each of the xix_ixi​ are a function uiu_iui​ of lll variables t1,t2,...,tlt_1, t_2, ..., t_lt1​,t2​,...,tl​. Then for all i=1,2,...,li = 1, 2, ..., li=1,2,...,l, we have

∂f∂ti=∑j=1m∂f∂xj∂xj∂ti\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_i} = \sum_{j=1}^m \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_j}\frac{\partial x_j}{\partial t_i}∂ti​∂f​=j=1∑m​∂xj​∂f​∂ti​∂xj​​

(Note that this is a notational simplification because it doesn't display the variables that are being held constant - e.g. if you wanted to be really, really scrupulous you could write (∂f∂x1)x2,x3,...,xm(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1})_{x_2,x_3,...,x_m}(∂x1​∂f​)x2​,x3​,...,xm​​ to demonstrate that x1x_1x1​ is the variable differentiated with respect to and the other variables are constant!)

Corollary. The above equation can be written in matrix form as

S=TU,S = TU,S=TU,

in which SSS is the n×ln \times ln×l matrix of partial derivative components of fff w.r.t. t1,t2,...,tlt_1, t_2, ..., t_lt1​,t2​,...,tl​:

S={(∂f∂tj)i}=[(∂f∂t1)1(∂f∂t2)1...(∂f∂tl)1(∂f∂t1)2(∂f∂t2)2...(∂f∂tl)2⋮⋮⋱⋮(∂f∂t1)n(∂f∂t2)n...(∂f∂tl)n]S = \{(\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_j})_i\} = \begin{bmatrix} (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_1})_1 & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_2})_1 & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_l})_1 \\ (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_1})_2 & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_2})_2 & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_l})_2 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_1})_n & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_2})_n & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial t_l})_n \end{bmatrix}S={(∂tj​∂f​)i​}=⎣⎡​(∂t1​∂f​)1​(∂t1​∂f​)2​⋮(∂t1​∂f​)n​​(∂t2​∂f​)1​(∂t2​∂f​)2​⋮(∂t2​∂f​)n​​......⋱...​(∂tl​∂f​)1​(∂tl​∂f​)2​⋮(∂tl​∂f​)n​​⎦⎤​

TTT is the n×mn \times mn×m matrix recalled from the previous section as the matrix of the partial derivative components of fff w.r.t. x1,x2,...,xmx_1, x_2, ..., x_mx1​,x2​,...,xm​:

T={(∂f∂xj)i}=[(∂f∂x1)1(∂f∂x2)1...(∂f∂xm)1(∂f∂x1)2(∂f∂x2)2...(∂f∂xm)2⋮⋮⋱⋮(∂f∂x1)n(∂f∂x2)n...(∂f∂xm)n]T = \{(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_j})_i\} = \begin{bmatrix} (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1})_1 & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2})_1 & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_m})_1 \\ (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1})_2 & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2})_2 & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_m})_2 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1})_n & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2})_n & ... & (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_m})_n \end{bmatrix}T={(∂xj​∂f​)i​}=⎣⎡​(∂x1​∂f​)1​(∂x1​∂f​)2​⋮(∂x1​∂f​)n​​(∂x2​∂f​)1​(∂x2​∂f​)2​⋮(∂x2​∂f​)n​​......⋱...​(∂xm​∂f​)1​(∂xm​∂f​)2​⋮(∂xm​∂f​)n​​⎦⎤​

and UUU is the m×lm \times lm×l matrix of partial derivatives of x1,x2,...,xmx_1, x_2, ..., x_mx1​,x2​,...,xm​ w.r.t. t1,t2,...,tlt_1, t_2, ..., t_lt1​,t2​,...,tl​:

U={(∂xi∂tj)}=[∂x1∂t1∂x1∂t2...∂x1∂tl∂x2∂t1∂x2∂t2...∂x2∂tl⋮⋮⋱⋮∂xm∂t1∂xm∂t2...∂xm∂tl]U = \{(\frac{\partial x_i}{\partial t_j})\} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t_1} & \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t_2} & ... & \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t_l} \\ \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t_1} & \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t_2} & ... & \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t_l} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial x_m}{\partial t_1} & \frac{\partial x_m}{\partial t_2} & ... & \frac{\partial x_m}{\partial t_l} \end{bmatrix}U={(∂tj​∂xi​​)}=⎣⎡​∂t1​∂x1​​∂t1​∂x2​​⋮∂t1​∂xm​​​∂t2​∂x1​​∂t2​∂x2​​⋮∂t2​∂xm​​​......⋱...​∂tl​∂x1​​∂tl​∂x2​​⋮∂tl​∂xm​​​⎦⎤​

Call these matrix the Jacobian matrices of f(x)\mathbf{f(x)}f(x).

Example of the chain rule applied to a change of coordinates (Cartesian to polar).

Suppose that z=f(x,y)z = f(x,y)z=f(x,y) describes the height of a point (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) on your bedsheets this morning after I "befriended" your mom last night. Because your mom emits both the gravitational and magnetic fields characteristic of an Earth-sized planet, we have decided to convert (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) to polar coordinates (x(ρ,θ),y(ρ,θ))(x(\rho, \theta), y(\rho,\theta))(x(ρ,θ),y(ρ,θ)) (they are more applicable to problems which revolve around a globe). What is the rate of change of zzz w.r.t. ρ\rhoρ and θ\thetaθ?

A notational clarification is required here:

Notation. If f(x,y)=f(x(ρ,θ),y(ρ,θ))f(x,y) = f(x(\rho, \theta), y(\rho, \theta))f(x,y)=f(x(ρ,θ),y(ρ,θ)) (or any such combination of variables), fff can be written as a function of ρ\rhoρ and θ\thetaθ. Thus write f(x,y)=F(ρ,θ)f(x,y) = F(\rho, \theta)f(x,y)=F(ρ,θ).

In this case, we have (x,y)=(ρcos⁡θ,ρsin⁡θ)(x,y) = (\rho \cos \theta, \rho \sin \theta)(x,y)=(ρcosθ,ρsinθ) by polar coordinates. By the chain rule we have

(∂f∂ρ)θ=(∂f∂x)y(∂x∂ρ)θ+(∂f∂y)x(∂y∂ρ)θ=(∂f∂x)ycos⁡θ+(∂f∂y)xsin⁡θ\begin{aligned} (\frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho})_{\theta} &= (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y(\frac{\partial x}{\partial \rho})_\theta + (\frac{\partial f}{\partial y})_x(\frac{\partial y}{\partial \rho})_\theta \\ &= (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y\cos \theta + (\frac{\partial f}{\partial y})_x\sin \theta \\ \end{aligned}(∂ρ∂f​)θ​​=(∂x∂f​)y​(∂ρ∂x​)θ​+(∂y∂f​)x​(∂ρ∂y​)θ​=(∂x∂f​)y​cosθ+(∂y∂f​)x​sinθ​

being careful to note which variables are kept constant, and

(∂f∂θ)ρ=(∂f∂x)y∂x∂θ+(∂f∂y)x∂y∂θ=−(∂f∂x)yρsin⁡θ+(∂f∂y)xρcos⁡θ=−y(∂f∂x)y+x(∂f∂y)x\begin{aligned} (\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta})_{\rho} &= (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y\frac{\partial x}{\partial \theta} + (\frac{\partial f}{\partial y})_x\frac{\partial y}{\partial \theta} \\ &= -(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y\rho \sin \theta + (\frac{\partial f}{\partial y})_x\rho \cos \theta \\ &= - y (\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y + x (\frac{\partial f}{\partial y})_x \end{aligned}(∂θ∂f​)ρ​​=(∂x∂f​)y​∂θ∂x​+(∂y∂f​)x​∂θ∂y​=−(∂x∂f​)y​ρsinθ+(∂y∂f​)x​ρcosθ=−y(∂x∂f​)y​+x(∂y∂f​)x​​

As ρ=x2+y2\rho = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}ρ=x2+y2​ and θ=tan⁡−1(yx)\theta = \tan^{-1}(\frac{y}{x})θ=tan−1(xy​) are both functions of xxx and yyy, we can also obtain expressions for ∂f∂xy\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}_y∂x∂f​y​ and ∂f∂yx\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}_x∂y∂f​x​ from the chain rule based on ρ\rhoρ and θ\thetaθ, e.g.

(∂f∂x)y=(∂f∂ρ)θ(∂ρ∂x)y+(∂f∂θ)ρ(∂θ∂x)y(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x})_y = (\frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho})_{\theta} (\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x})_y + (\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta})_{\rho} (\frac{\partial \theta}{\partial x})_y(∂x∂f​)y​=(∂ρ∂f​)θ​(∂x∂ρ​)y​+(∂θ∂f​)ρ​(∂x∂θ​)y​

noting crucially that (∂ρ∂x)y(\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x})_y(∂x∂ρ​)y​ keeps yyy constant, not θ\thetaθ.
